references: In this section, we first introduce AIGC-empowered FL paradigm. We further characterize clientsâ€™ attributes, clientsâ€™ utility functions and serverâ€™s utility function. Finally, we propose data quality-aware incentive mechanism under complete and incomplete information scenarios. For readability, we summarize the key notations in Table I.

references: Fig. 17 and Table IV show the difference of serverâ€™s cost between complete and incomplete information scenario and the corresponding averaged unit data reward benchmark rğ‘Ÿr for the two cases. To reduce the error caused by randomness, we conduct experiments 101010 times and average the results for the two cases. As depicted in Fig. 17, when Kâ‰¥20ğ¾20K\geq 20, the difference of serverâ€™s costs between complete and incomplete information scenarios decreases with the increase of the number of candidate clients Kğ¾K. When K=10ğ¾10K=10, the difference of serverâ€™s costs between the two information scenarios is the lowest, since the server recruits clients with AIGC-enhanced datasets by setting r=Î¶3=0.6238ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğœ30.6238r=\zeta_{3}=0.6238 in incomplete information scenario. In essence, in instances where the amount of candidate clients is limited, the introduction of AIGC-enhanced datasets serves to alleviate serverâ€™s costs stemming from information asymmetry. However, as the quantity of candidate clients escalates, thereâ€™s a rise in the presence of high-quality clients (exhibiting lower Î»ksubscriptğœ†ğ‘˜\lambda_{k} and lower sksubscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜s_{k}). Consequently, the serverâ€™s reliance on generated data diminishes. Conversely, offering a uniformly increased rğ‘Ÿr to a larger number of clients which use AIGC-enhanced datasets will result in heightened payments to clients.
